pullRequest.body:
We generalize [Ideal.spanNorm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Norm/RelNorm.html#Ideal.spanNorm) to allow non-free extensions.

Currently, `spanNorm`, is defined as
```lean
def spanNorm (R : Type*) [CommRing R] {S : Type*} [CommRing S] [Algebra R S] (I : Ideal S) : Ideal R :=
    Ideal.span (Algebra.norm R '' (I : Set S))
```
but the definition is mathematically meaningless unless `[Module.Finite R S]` and `[Module.Free R S]`. We change this to
```lean
def spanNorm (R : Type*) [CommRing R] [IsDomain R] {S : Type*} [CommRing S] [IsDomain S]
    [IsIntegrallyClosed R] [IsIntegrallyClosed S] [Algebra R S] [Module.Finite R S] [NoZeroSMulDivisors R S]
    [Algebra.IsSeparable (FractionRing R) (FractionRing S)] (I : Ideal S) : Ideal R :=
  Ideal.span (Algebra.intNorm R S '' (I : Set S))
```
that is the mathematically correct definition, notably in the case `R` and `S` are the rings of integers in an extension of number fields.


From flt-regular

Co-authored-by: Andrew Yang <a.yang24@imperial.ac.uk>

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message

Current commit [2bc602bfe4](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/2bc602bfe43f88cc52d5d9bd6fd82012d62e6ba4)

./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> In reviewing the main changes (to `RelNorm`) I agree that the current notion is meaningless if the above algebra is not (finite, and) free over the one below, but adding that everything is integrally closed seems too much. I can very well imagine taking the norm down to `Z` from a ring that is not a ring of integers (and this is actually very useful if you study orders in number fields). Am I missing something?

This is because `Algebra.intNorm` wants it. I agree it is not yet general enough, but I think we can generalize this later (since `IsIntegrallyClosed` is a class this shouldn't be a pain to do)

> > In reviewing the main changes (to `RelNorm`) I agree that the current notion is meaningless if the above algebra is not (finite, and) free over the one below, but adding that everything is integrally closed seems too much. I can very well imagine taking the norm down to `Z` from a ring that is not a ring of integers (and this is actually very useful if you study orders in number fields). Am I missing something?
> 
> This is because `Algebra.intNorm` wants it. I agree it is not yet general enough, but I think we can generalize this later (since `IsIntegrallyClosed` is a class this shouldn't be a pain to do)

Ok, I have been thinking about this for a while and I am slowly trying to make my mind. Just to be sure, do you agree that with your proposed change we are _losing_ the definition of the norm down to `Z` of an ideal in an arbitrary ring that is finite and torsion-free over the integers?

> > > In reviewing the main changes (to `RelNorm`) I agree that the current notion is meaningless if the above algebra is not (finite, and) free over the one below, but adding that everything is integrally closed seems too much. I can very well imagine taking the norm down to `Z` from a ring that is not a ring of integers (and this is actually very useful if you study orders in number fields). Am I missing something?
> > 
> > 
> > This is because `Algebra.intNorm` wants it. I agree it is not yet general enough, but I think we can generalize this later (since `IsIntegrallyClosed` is a class this shouldn't be a pain to do)
> 
> Ok, I have been thinking about this for a while and I am slowly trying to make my mind. Just to be sure, do you agree that with your proposed change we are _losing_ the definition of the norm down to `Z` of an ideal in an arbitrary ring that is finite and torsion-free over the integers?

Yes. Currently the definition works from orders to `â„¤`, but not in the relative case (not even from `ð“ž L` to `ð“ž K`). What I am proposing doesn't work for orders, but works in the relative case. Of course we want both generalizations, but I think it is more reasonable to have this at the beginning (note that in practice this is only used from `ð“ž K` to `â„¤`).

Removing `IsIntegrallyClosed` (from `Algebra.intNorm`) is probably not very difficult, and once this is done it will automatically be removed from `spanNorm` (since it is a typeclass the linter will flag where it is not needed).

I somewhat agree that removing `IntegrallyClosed` should not be too hard (keeping noetherianity) , although Bourbaki asks for it in _AlgÃ¨bre Commutative, Chap. VI, Â§4, no. 8_ which was my starting point for proposing a generalisation. On the other hand, dimension 1 (so, Dedekind) is certainly superfluous. I will try to think a little bit more about this.

given that nobody can offer a concrete use case away from the integrally closed situation, and given that we definitely need it in the non-free situation, and given that this is what Bourbaki does, I think we should merge this and worry later on about hypothetical generalizations.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13111301649/job/36575644675)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13111301649/job/36575644372)
We were discussing this with @riccardobrasca in private DM's, I think now it's done but I find it slightly a pity that we are loosing something.

> We were discussing this with @riccardobrasca in private DM's, I think now it's done but I find it slightly a pity that we are loosing something.

You should have come to the triage meeting :P

More seriously, the point is that there are surely applications of the new definition (the relative norm map), but we didn't see any application of the case when the rings are not integrally closed but the big one is still free over the small one (of course this can happen, but it seems like a much more specific case).

In reviewing the main changes (to `RelNorm`) I agree that the current notion is meaningless if the above algebra is not (finite, and) free over the one below, but adding that everything is integrally closed seems too much. I can very well imagine taking the norm down to `Z` from a ring that is not a ring of integers (and this is actually very useful if you study orders in number fields). Am I missing something?
I have just started the review and have a couple of comments (above), I will dig into the math later on.

In reviewing the main changes (to `RelNorm`) I agree that the current notion is meaningless if the above algebra is not (finite, and) free over the one below, but adding that everything is integrally closed seems too much. I can very well imagine taking the norm down to `Z` from a ring that is not a ring of integers (and this is actually very useful if you study orders in number fields). Am I missing something?
This sequence of `have` is not very nice. I am open to any suggestion.
What's the point of a `haveI` here?
`IsLocalization.isDomain_of_le_nonZeroDivisors` is not an instance (and it cannot be), without this line Lean doesn't know that `Sâ‚š` is a domain.
If you mean that it can be an `have` then I agree (fixing it).
Yes, that's what I meant.

I might misunderstand the situation, but I would say that this lemma holds without assuming that `R_p` and `S_p` are rings, you just need to know that they are localizations of `R` and `S` at `M` and at the image of `M` (and that `M` is made of non-zero divisors, of course). No?
Do you mean I don't need addition? `IsLocalization` is defined only for semirings.

No, what I meant is that I do not think that you need `S` (and so `S_p`) to be `R`-algebras, they only need to be `R`-modules. I would then expect to use [IsLocalizedModule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LocalizedModule/Basic.html#IsLocalizedModule)  instead of `IsLocalization` for `S_p`; but you would need to manually provide the morphism from `R` to `S`, and perhaps to ask that the image of `M` is a monoid and that it satisfies `NoZeroSmulDivisors`. 

I agree this can look a bit strange, but since the conclusion only pertains to the `R_p`-module structure of `S_p`, it seems to me that you are only using the algebra structures involved to have nice morphisms (which can be achieved by asking that such morphisms exist), and not because you really need `S` or `S_p` to be themselves rings.

I get the idea, but in practice I don't see a precise statement. If `S` is not a ring but only an `R`-module, what is the morphism from `R` to `S`? And If `S` is a ring then any localization as `R`-module is automatically a ring.
This new import is needed because of the very recent modification #19376. It seems harmless to import `Algebra.Algebra.Tower`.

This could be written as
```
  Ideal.map (Algebra.intNorm R S) I
```
(and then some simps below need to have `Ideal.map` added).

This definition is definitely a good idea for rings of integers of number fields, because we definitely want to take the norm of an ideal there, but it also means that we lose the ability to take the norm of an ideal of S when S is finite free as an R-module but R is not an integrally closed domain. Might we one day care about this situation?

Yes, we loose something here. I *think* it is more interesting to have the relative case, at least at the beginning. Serre does everything in the AKLB setup, and also Bourbaki seems to assume `A` integrally closed.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: generalize `Ideal.spanNorm` to allow non free extensions
